Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Situation2: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, phone in hand, rereading the message from my friend. “I can’t believe you’d say that to me,” she’d written, her words sharp and wounded. My heart pounded—I hadn’t meant it that way at all. I knew I needed to call her, to explain, to fix this before it grew into something bigger. But just as I reached for the phone, my stepdad walked in, his face drawn and tired. He sat down across from me, eyes searching mine, and started talking about how lost he felt since the divorce, how he didn’t know if he was doing enough for me or for himself. He needed me to listen, to reassure him, to be the steady presence he was looking for. I felt pulled in two directions—my friend needed me to be honest and present, but my stepdad needed me to be strong and supportive. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out who needed me more in that moment, and how I could possibly be enough for both.
